title: 105_s2466
content: Commemorative coins are being issued to honor the founding of Biloxi, Mississippi. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $10 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition requirements. The coins minted under this section will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to the specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and the design shall be emblematic of the landing of Pierre LeMoyne Sieur D'Iberville. The Secretary will obtain gold and silver for minting coins under this section from various sources. The coins minted under this section will bear a designation of the value, inscription of the year 1999, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant commissions. The Secretary may issue coins minted in 1999 with specific designs and inscriptions. The coins will be sold at a price including face value, surcharge, and production costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders are accepted. The Secretary may accept prepaid orders for coins minted under specific designs and inscriptions, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. Surcharges apply to all sales, and procurement of goods and services is exempt from certain regulations. For the procurement of goods and services under this section, equal employment opportunity laws must be followed. Coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items. Surcharges from coin sales are to be promptly paid to the Biloxi Tricentennial Commission, Inc. for planning and implementing the 1999 event. The Biloxi Tricentennial Commission, Inc. is responsible for planning and implementing the 1999 Tricentennial Celebration in Biloxi, Mississippi. Upon dissolution, funds will be transferred to Biloxi First, Inc. for educational projects related to local history instruction. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the expenditures of both organizations. The Secretary will ensure financial assurances for minting and issuing coins. The Secretary will ensure financial assurances for minting and issuing coins to prevent any net cost to the United States Government.
